In addition, all types of public receptors (schools, residences, hospitals, prisons, public recreation areas or arenas, major commercial or industrial areas) and environmental receptors (national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, or refuges; federal wilderness areas) within this distance should be identified.

A field survey was used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the flammable endpoint and to identify public receptors.  The survey showed that no population is within the 0.4 mile impact radius for the worst case release. The impact area on a map is demonstrated in appendix A. The types of public receptors and environmental receptors identified within the impact area are listed in Table 2-2.  Google Earth was used to find the public receptors within the impact radius. Additionally, no environmental receptors are impacted by the worst-case release scenario.

Program 1 Risk Management Plan
Hidatsa North Pad
WPX Energy, Inc.
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Montana Dakota Services operates a J-T skid designed to recover propane, butane and natural gasoline from gas prior to gathering and final treatment for WPX Energy, Inc. (WPX) at the Hidatsa North Pad.  This report provides the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the recovery skid system, pursuant to the requirements of the U.S. EPA RMP rule.

The system is designed to remove liquids from gas at the wellhead, having an inlet pressure between 150 and 400 psi.  The J-T valve system can generate temperatures as low as -20°F.  Montana Dakota Services uses this system to remove liquids from flared gases.  The portability of the unit allows it to easily be moved from site to site when flaring ceases.  The NGL storage tanks have an 18,000 gallon capacity. Montana Dakota Services will have two tanks onsite and the maximum fill for each tank is 14,400 gallons. The 28,800 gallons is equivalent to 164,448 lbs. of flammable liquids.

Under the authority of section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act, the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions require facilities that produce, handle, process, distribute, or store certain chemicals to develop a Risk Management Program, prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP), and submit the RMP to EPA. Covered facilities were initially required to comply with the rule in 1999, and the rule has been amended on several occasions since then, most recently in 2004. This facility is regulated under Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68), more commonly known as the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. RMP plans must be prepared for processes that store in excess of the thresholds set forth by 40 CFR 68.130. For flammable liquids, the threshold is 10,000 lbs.  Montana Dakota Services can store approximately 164,448 lbs. of NGL and exceeds 10,000 lbs. threshold, thus the facility is subject to the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention rule a

nd must prepare a RMP.

LOCATION

The Hidatsa North Pad is located in the NW ¼ of the SE ¼ of section 11, Township 150N, Range 93W, Mountrail County, North Dakota, on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation (FBIR).

Latitude: 47.824639, Longitude: -102.542866

DRIVING DIRECTIONS
Proceed in a Southerly direction from New Town, ND along 89th Ave NW/West Ave. approximately 3.1 miles to the junction of this road and 36th St. NW; turn right and proceed in a Westerly direction approximately 3.0 miles to the junction of this road and 92nd Ave. NW; turn left and proceed in a Southerly direction approximately 7.1 miles on 92nd Ave. NW to a point where the road curves East; continue in an Easterly direction approximately 0.6 miles on 29th St. NW; continue through curve in a Southeasterly direction on 91st Ave. NW for 0.4 miles to the intersection of this and the proposed access road; turn right and proceed in an Southwesterly direction approximately 0.5 miles to the Hidatsa North Pad.

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS: POPULATION AND ENVIRONMENT
